trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Randomised, Double-blind Study of Pravastatin for the Treatment of Hyperlipidaemia in Patients with HIV
trial_identification.secondaryid: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute of the National Institutes of Health: R01 HL65953-01

interventions.interventions: This study is a randomised, placebo-controlled study of the effect of 12 weeks treatment with the HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, pravastatin, in HIV-infected, protease inhibitor treated patients with high serum cholesterol. We hypothesise that pravastatin will result in greater reductions in cholesterol than placebo when used in conjunction with appropriate dietary advice.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The between-group difference in time weighted change from baseline in fasting serum total cholesterol.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: i. between-group difference in time weighted change from week 4 in fasting serum total cholesterol (start of pravastatin).
ii. individual changes in fasting total cholesterol at each measured time point.
iii. between-group difference in time weighted change from baseline in HDL-cholesterol and triglycerides, change from baseline glucose, insulin.
iv. between-group difference in change from baseline in total and regional body fat.
v. between-group difference in change from baseline in endothelial function and peripheral blood markers of cardiovascular risk.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Provide written informed consent to participate in the trial - HIV-1 sero-positive - Currently receiving HIV protease inhibitor therapy for > 12 weeks and unlikely to require change in existing regimen during the 16 week study period- Fasting cholesterol > 6.5 mmol/L (mean of 2 samples collected > 3 days apart)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Gastrointestinal disorder which may affect drug absorption- Hypertension or congestive cardiac failure- Lactic acidemia (serum lactate level >2.2 mmol/L)- Any serious medical condition which may compromise the patients safety, including pancreatitis or hepatitis within past 6 months- Active AIDS defining conditions- Concurrent therapy with any other lipid lowering agents, oral hypoglycaemics, anabolic steroids or insulin.

trial_design.concealment: Subjects were randomised on a 1:1 ratio to either active drug or matched placebo. Randomisation was performed by the hospital pharmacy and the study investigators were blinded as to randomised allocation.
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation sequence was generated by the study statistician.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The University of New South Wales

fundingsource.fundingname: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study is a randomised, placebo-controlled study of the effect of treatment with the HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, pravastatin, in HIV-infected, protease inhibitor treated patients with high serum cholesterol. We hypothesise that pravastatin will result in greater reductions in cholesterol than placebo when used in conjunction with appropriate dietary advice.

contact.address: National Centre in HIV Epidemiology and Clinical Research (NCHECR) Level 2 376 Victoria Street Darlinghurst NSW 2010
